title: Read & Explore a Text Dataset
description:
Given a text string stored in the variable `text`, compute three things:

1. `total_chars` — the total number of characters in the text.
2. `unique_chars` — a **sorted** list of all unique characters that appear in the text.
3. `vocab_size` — the number of unique characters (i.e., the size of the character vocabulary).

These values are the foundation for building a character-level language model: you need to know what characters exist before you can map them to numbers.

text = "First Citizen:
Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

All:
Speak, speak.

First Citizen:
You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

All:
Resolved. resolved.

First Citizen:
First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.

All:
We know't, we know't.

First Citizen:
Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price.
Is't a verdict?

All:
No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!
"

solutionCode:
text = "First Citizen:
Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

All:
Speak, speak.

First Citizen:
You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

All:
Resolved. resolved.

First Citizen:
First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.

All:
We know't, we know't.

First Citizen:
Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price.
Is't a verdict?

All:
No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!
"

total_chars = len(text)

unique_chars = sorted(list(set(text)))

vocab_size = len(unique_chars)
hints: Use len() to count total characters in a string.
set(text) gives you all unique characters. Convert it to a sorted list with sorted(list(set(text))).
vocab_size is simply len(unique_chars) — the number of distinct characters.
